Award.AwardTitle: GOALI/Collaborative Research: Fundamentals of Microemulsion Boiling: from Interfacial Thermodynamics to Multiphase Heat Transfer

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1336778/1336590

PI: Yang/Qiao

The objective of this collaborative GOALI project is to investigate the fundamental mechanisms of nucleate boiling in microemulsions and to evaluate their performance and reliability in industry-relevant cooling systems. The PIs have identified an interesting microemulsion fluid, in which a volatile liquid is dispersed into another immiscible nonvolatile liquid as self-assembled droplets, as a candidate for enhanced phase change heat transfer. It has been observed that the polyalphaolefin-based microemulsion fluids exhibit a pool boiling critical heat flux (CHF) about 80% higher than the base fluid polyalphaolefin. To enable the rational design of microemulsions as heat transfer fluids and to fully exploit their potential in boiling, three interwoven activities will be carried out in this project. First, the PIs will investigate the interfacial thermodynamics of microemulsions at elevated temperatures and understand the energetics of phase change in microemulsions. Second, the PIs will investigate the heat transfer mechanisms of microemulsion boiling by integrating experimental characterization and numerical simulations. The research will focus on the peculiar bubble dynamics that differ greatly from those in classical pool boiling. Third, the PIs will evaluate the performance of microemulsion boiling under industry-relevant settings through collaboration with industrial partners. The proposed research is potentially transformative: by introducing microemulsions as heat transfer fluids, whose boiling behavior differs qualitatively from classical boiling, this work pioneers a radically new approach for enhancing boiling heat transfer.

The proposed research helps resolve a long-standing challenge in high-heat flux cooing and can potentially enable new breakthroughs in many technologies limited by current bottlenecks in cooling. In particular, this research can greatly benefit two industrial sectors: thermal management of electronics and industrial heat exchangers. Initiating the GOALI partnership between University of Maryland, Clemson University and their industrial partner will greatly enhance their research capabilities and facilitate the application of microemulsions in industrial thermal management systems. The proposed project will be tied closely with the education activities at University of Maryland and Clemson University through training students in interdisciplinary research, broadening the participation of underrepresented groups in research, and K-12 outreach. When implementing these activities, the PIs will focus on broadening the horizons of students through research at frontiers of engineering sciences and exposing students to real-life industry problems. These activities will be carried by making full use of available institutional resources and by leveraging collaboration with industrial partner.

Institution.Name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INSTITUTE AND STATE UNIVERSITY

Performance_Institution.Name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University

ProgramReference.Text: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS
EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Boiling is widely used in thermal management applications involving high heat fluxes. One of the main obstacles in boiling heat transfer is that the maximally achievable heat flux, often termed critical heat flux (CHF), is limited by the transition from the nucleate to the film boiling mode. The CHF can be increased by methods such as introducing textures to heat transfer surfaces or optimizing the heat transfer fluids. In this project, the team investigated the boiling heat transfer of microemulsions because some microemulsion exhibits superior CHF. The microemulsion is typically prepared by dispersing a volatile liquid (e.g., water) into an immiscible nonvolatile liquid (e.g., polyalphaolefin) as self-assembled droplets with the help of surfactants. While microemulsions have been extensively studied in applications such as chemical reactions and oil recovery, little is understood about their boiling heat transfer.

In this project, two critical aspects of boiling of microemulsions were investigated using numerical simulations. First, the thermal decomposition of water-in-oil microemulsion droplets was studied. The breakdown of the microemulsion droplets, the release of their water molecules, and the associated energy change were computed and the underlying mechanisms were clarified. Second, the formation and growth dynamics of bubbles driven by the diffusion and convection of supersaturated gas molecules in liquids were studied. The dependence of the bubble formation on the curvature of solid surfaces was clarified. The growth of single and multiple bubbles on solid surfaces was computed and the underlying mechanisms were clarified.

Overall, the studies pursued in this project provided fundamental insights into the boiling of a novel class of heat transfer fluids and helped lay the foundation for future research to rationally design and optimize these fluids to achieve even higher CHFs. The research thus will benefit broad technical areas in which phase change heat transfer is used for cooling. The research findings of this project have been published in peer-reviewed journals, presented in professional conferences, and presented to the undergraduate students at Virginia Tech. The research has also been shared with K-12 students and their families in the Science Festival, an annual outreach event at Virginia Tech. 

 


Last Modified: 10/28/2018
Modified by: Rui Qiao
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Boiling is widely used in thermal management applications involving high heat fluxes. One of the main obstacles in boiling heat transfer is that the maximally achievable heat flux, often termed critical heat flux (CHF), is limited by the transition from the nucleate to the film boiling mode. The CHF can be increased by methods such as introducing textures to heat transfer surfaces or optimizing the heat transfer fluids. In this project, the team investigated the boiling heat transfer of microemulsions because some microemulsion exhibits superior CHF. The microemulsion is typically prepared by dispersing a volatile liquid (e.g., water) into an immiscible nonvolatile liquid (e.g., polyalphaolefin) as self-assembled droplets with the help of surfactants. While microemulsions have been extensively studied in applications such as chemical reactions and oil recovery, little is understood about their boiling heat transfer. In this project, two critical aspects of boiling of microemulsions were investigated using numerical simulations. First, the thermal decomposition of water-in-oil microemulsion droplets was studied. The breakdown of the microemulsion droplets, the release of their water molecules, and the associated energy change were computed and the underlying mechanisms were clarified. Second, the formation and growth dynamics of bubbles driven by the diffusion and convection of supersaturated gas molecules in liquids were studied. The dependence of the bubble formation on the curvature of solid surfaces was clarified. The growth of single and multiple bubbles on solid surfaces was computed and the underlying mechanisms were clarified. Overall, the studies pursued in this project provided fundamental insights into the boiling of a novel class of heat transfer fluids and helped lay the foundation for future research to rationally design and optimize these fluids to achieve even higher CHFs. The research thus will benefit broad technical areas in which phase change heat transfer is used for cooling. The research findings of this project have been published in peer-reviewed journals, presented in professional conferences, and presented to the undergraduate students at Virginia Tech. The research has also been shared with K-12 students and their families in the Science Festival, an annual outreach event at Virginia Tech. Last Modified: 10/28/2018 Submitted by: Rui Qiao
